item.title: A year into learning Japanese
item.description: It‚Äôs been just over a year since I started learning Japanese so I thought it was a good time to stop, reflect over my journey and consider what I‚Äôve learnt.
item.content:encoded:
It‚Äôs been just over a year since I started learning Japanese so I thought it was a good time to stop, reflect over my journey and consider what I‚Äôve learnt. I started on 19th April 2020 and since then I‚Äôve dedicated 1,378 hours to studying (according to my timer app). That‚Äôs just over 25 hours a week, quite a lot on top of a full time job. In this post, I will try to justify how I spent that much time on one hobby (neglecting everything else in my life) as well as point people to the resources I used.

How did I learn Japanese?

Setting goals

I‚Äôm one of those cool kids that likes to set goals for myself even outside of work. So in order to make sure I was taking Japanese seriously, I set some goals up front. A lot of these were around passing a set of exams called the JLPT (Japanese-Language Proficiency Test). Unfortunately, I couldn‚Äôt take these in person (because of the whole COVID thing) but I did take the mock papers on the dates I set in advance. Happily, I "passed" N5 with a result of 91% in July, N4 with 91% in August and N3 with 80% in December. I‚Äôm planning to take a mock N2 test on July 4th, the day the exam would have happened in London if it hadn‚Äôt been cancelled. And hopefully, I‚Äôll be able to take the real thing in December and have a shiny certificate to show for it (plus, validate all the work I put in).

The other goal I set for myself way back in April 2020 was to read and finish Harry Potter and the Philosopher‚Äôs Stone, in Japanese, by the end of the year. Frankly, it took me ages to do so, but I did finish the book and wrote about it another blog post to celebrate the occassion.

Learning how to learn

At the very beginning, I spent a good deal of time researching how to learn Japanese. Being a spoiled native English speaker, my main exposure to formal language learning was (not really) learning German at school. My first baby step, therefore, was to learm how to learn. On one of my internet explorations, I found a 177 page Google Doc that detailed the author‚Äôs experience learning Japanese and their recommended approach. It‚Äôs packed with information so I suggest checking it out if you want to learn Japanese and don‚Äôt know where to start.

After reading skimming over this document, I started to reframe what learning Japanese actually meant. Before, I had this idea that I would be training a particular skill (the ability to Japanese?) But it turns out language acquisition is a bit more complex than that and includes multiple skills. There are passive skills, such as listening and reading, which determine how well you can understand Japanese in different settings. As well as active skills, speaking and writing, which determine how well you can communciate. Underpinning all these skills are the building blocks of the language, grammar and vocabulary.

Structuring my language learning around these building blocks and skills allowed me to allocate my time most effectively. Early on, I decided to prioritise listening and reading over speaking and writing. I knew it would be much easier to find Japanese audio and text than it is to befriend people who could speak the language, something I wasn‚Äôt yet confident enough to do. I could also shift my focus depending on the parts of the language I was weakest at. This was an ongoing analysis that I could do, say, when I was reading a book and noticed that I was spending more time looking up kanji and vocab than I was on grammar points. Or when I struggled to understand a sentence when it was written down but could comprehend it instantly when it was spoken aloud in an audiobook. These kind of observations meant that I could continually tweak my study plan to get the most out of learning Japanese.

Kanji and vocabulary

I spent a significant chunk (nearly 600 hours) of my time learning kanji and vocabulary. It was the area I spent the most time in because kanji is simply the hardest part of the language, and one where I didn‚Äôt have a head start in. There are thousands of kanji characters and it‚Äôs one of the reasons why Japanese is considered the hardest language for a native English speaker to learn.

I researched a few ways I could learn kanji and ultimately decided on WaniKani. It‚Äôs a web app that teaches kanji and vocabulary using mnemonics and spaced repetition. It‚Äôs quite pricey ($299 for a lifetime subscription) but, unlike free resources, everything is laid out for you. All you need to do is turn up, learn some stuff and try to progress to the next level. As you progress through the levels and finally take down the boss at level 60 (the boss might be made-up), you‚Äôll have learned over 2000 kanji. You‚Äôll have also learned 8000 supplementary vocabulary which contain the kanji you learned and are there to solidify your knowledge.

I actually reached level 60 a week ago! I still have a ton of items to review but have otherwise completed the course. Having just over 2000 kanji floating around my brain is a massive help when I want to read practically anything. There are still quite a lot of characters that I encounter in the wild that I don‚Äôt know. But I am confident I have the tools to learn more kanji once I come across them.

Grammar

Compared to kanji and vocabulary, I didn‚Äôt spend a significant amount of time studying grammar. In fact I only spent 90 hours doing so. Thankfully, I already had an inuitive understanding of common grammar patterns that was ingrained in me from when I was a child. So when I didn‚Äôt understand something, very rarely was it because of my lack of familiarity with the grammar. Instead, it was usually because I had no idea what the kanji characters were or what the vocabulary meant.

When I did study grammar, I used textbooks (because that was what the internet suggested). I went through the very popular Genki I, Genki II and Tobira textbooks, in that order. They roughly teach N5, N4 and N3 level grammar respectively. Up next, I have the Êñ∞ÂÆåÂÖ®„Éû„Çπ„Çø„ÉºÊñáÊ≥ï Êó•Êú¨Ë™ûËÉΩÂäõË©¶È®ì N2 (New Kanzen Master Grammar JLPT N2) textbook which I will dive into soon.

Listening

I spent around 320 hours listening to Japanese in the past year. In the beginning, it was a skill far beyond my reading ability so it was a way to immerse myself in Japanese without having to do too much studying up front. I started with a Let's Play series on Stardew Valley. It‚Äôs a game I‚Äôve spent hundreds of hours on so I could pick up a lot of words just from the context. It was nice to be able to wind down in the evening and feel like I‚Äôm studying when all I‚Äôm doing is watching someone play Stardew Valley. I also listened to a lot of 'Let‚Äôs learn Japanese from small talk!' (podcast) when I was cooking and watched a bunch of anime when I was eating. (As an aside, AnimeFeminist is a great place to discover feminist-friendly anime, if you care about that sort of thing.) I even rewatched all of The Good Place with Japanese audio ‚Äî highly recommend.

Reading

I spent a similar amount on reading (314 hours) as I did on listening. I‚Äôm still better at understanding spoken Japanese than I am written Japanese but I have made huge strides in the past year. At the start, I could barely read hiragana and katakana (kanji isn‚Äôt the only writing system, just the hardest) and would struggle to read a NHK Easy News article. Now, I‚Äôm able to read whole books in Japanese and read my latest, the third in the Kiki‚Äôs Delivery Service series, at 68% of audiobook speed.

I‚Äôm still planning to read two books a month this year. I‚Äôve read four so far, so am a bit behind. But, I‚Äôm hoping to catch up as my reading speed improves. I also have a backlog of video games I‚Äôd like to get through at some point which will definitely challenge my reading ability.

Speaking

Pretty much the only person I speak to in Japanese is my mum. I‚Äôve spent 27 hours speaking Japanese in the past year so that‚Äôs 27 hours on the phone with my mum. I‚Äôve definitely improved since I started, but I think that‚Äôs mostly down to how much time I‚Äôve spent in the other areas of my study. Going forward, I might try to find a tutor on italki and even attempt to talk to strangers on HelloTalk, whenever I pluck up the courage to do so.

Writing

Finally, writing is the skill that I‚Äôve dedicated the least amount of time on (15 hours). I had planned to write a journal entry every day but I kind of fell out of habit on that one. At some point I will pick it up again but it is hard. As much as I can comprehend a fair amount when I‚Äôm listening or reading, being able to produce coherent Japanese on the fly is something I need more practice at. In terms of handwriting Japanese, I haven‚Äôt spent any time on it at all. Most of my life is spent on the computer and I barely handwrite in English anyway. So it‚Äôs on the bottom of my list of priorities at the moment.

Am I fluent?

The most common question I get when I tell people I‚Äôm learning Japanese is, "Are you fluent?" It seems like a fair question to ask, especially given the amount of time I‚Äôve spent on it. A quick Google search for "how long does it take to be fluent in a language" will give top answers in the range of 200 to 720 hours. So, given I‚Äôve spent 1,328 hours studying Japanese, surely I should be fluent many times over now, right?

No.

I have dedicated the next few paragraphs to explain why this isn‚Äôt the case. Hopefully, this will set expectations for new learners and more importantly, prove to myself that I‚Äôm not a horrendously slow learner.

What is fluency?

It‚Äôs time to question the question. 'Fluency' is quite an abstract concept and open to very different interpretations. Firstly, there‚Äôs the question of which skills you need to acquire to say you‚Äôre fluent. For example, you might think 'fluency' only refers to your ability to verbally communicate . This makes sense because for a long time the majority of the population were illiterate but were still viewed as 'fluent' in their native language. On the other hand, not knowing how to read or write in your target language does feel a bit incomplete. There are also other aspects to communicating successfully beyond language, such as gestures and cultural etiquette.

Secondly, there‚Äôs the question of what mastery you need attain to be classed as 'fluent'. Conversational fluency, in which you are able to converse on everyday topics (with room for mistakes), is a far cry from being able to eloquently express yourself on a range of complex topics.

I would argue that the term 'fluency' isn‚Äôt a very helpful term for measuring language acquistion at all. It‚Äôs too ambiguous and highly contextual. You might have a near faultless exchange with a native speaker about the weather, which convinces them that you‚Äôre fluent. But that evening, the waiter at a restaurant gives you an English menu after seeing the panic on your face trying to decipher Japanese text. In these situations, being perceived as 'fluent' is a fleeting state that you can attain or lose depending on the context and who you‚Äôre with.

When I think about how I‚Äôm progressing with Japanese, I always compare my Japanese with my English. This does set unachievable standards for acquiring Japanese. I already have 25 years of practice with English and still use it more frequently than I do Japanese. So it‚Äôs unlikely my Japanese will ever surpass my English. However, setting the bar at where my native language stands does make my North Star a lot less ambiguous. It also exposes the sheer amount of time learning a new language takes, which is often glossed over or outright fabricated by marketers trying to sell you something.

In the end, I can feel good about reading a book in Japanese or having a conversation with my mum but I don‚Äôt delude myself into thinking, "That‚Äôs it! I have mastered the language now." If I had tried to read the same sorts of things I do in English, such as technical books, or talk about the same sorts of things I do in English, such as philosophy or politics, I wouldn‚Äôt know where to start. Even writing this same blog post in Japanese seems like an impossible feat or at least, would take me several more years.

So I guess a better answer to the question, "Are you fluent?" is, "It depends."

What else have I learned?

One of the interesting things I have found about the past year is that I haven‚Äôt just learned Japanese. I have also developed a lot of other skills as a by-product.

Resilience

It‚Äôs worth saying that I picked up learning Japanese during the pandemic and I truly believe it‚Äôs what helped me not only get through it and but have one of the best years I have ever had. Someone recently said to me that developing resilience is a lot about having a clear direction of where you want to go, even in the midst of chaos. And that really spoke to what learning Japanese has given me. I had clear long term goals of what I wanted to achieve from the outset and I have, luckily, been able to focus on that even as the world fell apart around me.

Time management

My time management and discipline is way better than I ever thought it could be. I have been spending pretty much most of my free time studying, more than I ever did at university (when I didn‚Äôt even have a job to distract me). One of the things that helped me was using my timer app to time each study session. The app gives you a superficial rank depending on how much time you‚Äôve clocked in during the week. As trivial as it sounds, the idea of gaining or losing a rank often pushed me to study, even on days when I was more reluctant to do so.

Enjoyment

To my surprise, I found that I actually enjoy studying Japanese and the slow grind to get marginally better at the language every day. At the beginning, I set my sights on the end goal, getting good at Japanese, and never considered that I would enjoy the journey itself. In particular, I‚Äôve really enjoyed gamifying the learning process and tracking my progress across various metrics. I also love that I am able to peep into another world and consume untranslated materials, like news articles and books, that are inaccessible to most of the world‚Äôs population.

All in all, I highly recommend picking up a new language if you‚Äôre interested! In any case, it‚Äôs a good way to challenge your brain and delay the onset of Alzheimer‚Äôs and Dementia.

item.title: How I felt about inheriting ¬£200,000
item.description: There are a bunch of feelings to disentangle when you inherit a large sum of money. This is my story of how I confronted those feelings.
item.content:encoded:
People don‚Äôt like to talk about money, much less money that‚Äôs inherited. But as much as it is an extremely privileged situation to be in, there are a bunch of feelings to disentangle when you inherit a large sum of money. Especially if you‚Äôre not used to it and don‚Äôt come from a wealthy background. You have to navigate the grief you have for the person who has died, guilt for benefiting from their death, and anxiety over what to do with it all.

If you want resources, there are countless articles that explain the administrative process of what to do when someone dies. And there are many other dry personal finance articles that assume you want to maximise your return on your inheritance money. But I couldn‚Äôt find much out there that touch on the emotional side of inheritance. So that‚Äôs why I want to break the silence and describe the journey I went through. I also ended up doing something a bit unusual and not often talked about.

On 1st November 2019, my grandmother, Annai, died in a care home. We knew it was coming. She had been suffering from Alzheimer‚Äôs for a while. Before then, she had lived a long and mostly comfortable life. That was one consolation. In a way, we were also thankful that she passed away when she did. Just a few months later, and she could have been caught up in the pandemic. Like so many others, she could have died alone and with no one to mourn her at her funeral.

Not long after her death, my gran‚Äôs solicitor contacted my parents. They were appointed executors and that meant they were responsible for carrying out the wishes in my gran‚Äôs will. At this point, I found out that my gran had left two thirds of everything she had to my dad and the remaining third to me. I‚Äôm still unsure why she chose to do what she did. It‚Äôs much more common for a parent to leave everything to their child. I was two years old when she wrote that will. It felt strange that she placed so much faith in me, the tiny toddler I was at the time.

I knew my gran‚Äôs estate would be sizable. Before she moved into a care home close to my parents, she lived in Norfolk. I would visit every Christmas as a child. I had this impression of her as living in a completely different world to my own with its own set of rules that I hadn‚Äôt been taught yet. I never got the hang of laying the table correctly (I still can‚Äôt believe fish knives are a thing) and would awe at my school friends that my grandparents had a house ‚Äúwith a dining room!‚Äù But I didn‚Äôt know the specifics of how much money she actually had.

I was told I would be inheriting over ¬£200,000.

I was shocked. I still feel overwhelmed by the sheer size of it typing it out now. It was much more than anyone expected. My mum was the one who joyfully shared the news with me over a phone call. But I couldn‚Äôt share that joy. The knowledge of that money sent me spiralling into a whirlpool of questions and emotions I was too afraid to confront.

I felt deep shame and guilt. I didn‚Äôt deserve this money. I hadn‚Äôt done anything to earn it. I thought about my mum who worked as a part-time carer and cleaner into her 60s. It was hard, physical work. Every time she would come home exhausted, complaining how sore she was. And yet, her labour wasn‚Äôt valued. Only with help of state support could we afford to pay rent and put food on the table. It felt so unjust that I would have this much wealth at the age of 25 without lifting a finger for it.

I also felt like a fraud. I had carved part of my identity as being ‚Äúthe poor one‚Äù growing up especially as I was surrounded by middle-class, affluent peers. I did become a lot more privileged once I left home. I got to attend a big name university and later started working in a well-paying industry. I reconciled my identity by acknowledging that I was once poor but am relatively well-off now and extremely grateful for it. But this inheritance chucked another curve ball at me. It felt like I‚Äôd been immediately transformed into this out-of-touch rich kid, one of those that I used to envy at school.

It was because of these reasons, I decided to ignore my inheritance. I knew it would take a while for the money to eventually be transferred. There‚Äôs a bunch of administrative stuff that needed to happen first which could take up to a year or two. That gave me an excuse to suppress all my feelings and pretend this inheritance didn‚Äôt exist.

And I did that for about a year, I went about life as if nothing had happened. I didn‚Äôt think about the inheritance looming around the corner and started to forget it existed. I kept it a secret. I didn‚Äôt tell anyone except my partner who I anxiously asked at the time, ‚ÄúDo you think of me differently now?‚Äù When my parents asked what I planned to do with ‚Äúmy money‚Äù, I would say, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, it‚Äôs not my money‚Äù and change the subject.

A year after my gran died, I finally had to confront reality. The solicitor was about to finish tying everything up and my mum was starting to ask more demanding questions. Stuff like, whether I would be willing to give my parents part of my inheritance so they could afford a house.

The few times I did give much thought to my inheritance over the past year, I thought about charity. To be honest, my motivations weren‚Äôt entirely selfless. I thought giving to charity would take away some of the guilt I had. But then the question always turned to how much I should give away. I wondered if I would ever feel guilt-free if I kept any of it for myself.

I pondered over what the ‚Äúnormal‚Äù thing would be for someone in my position to do (twenty-something working in London). I guessed that most people would want to put down a large deposit for a house. It‚Äôs probably the only hope a lot of us have in affording somewhere in this city. But again, I was already in quite a lucky position where it was feasible that I could save up enough someday. I also wasn‚Äôt ready to settle down yet and make such a large commitment as buying a house. And the guilt was there too, always lurking.

So my mind came back to the idea of charity. As the pandemic drew on, there was an increasing sense of urgency to use that money to help others.

I reached out to the solicitor who was dealing with the estate and asked about inheritance tax. There is inheritance tax to pay on my gran‚Äôs estate because it is about ¬£25,000 (number yet to be finalised) over the threshold. I knew that any gifts to charity wouldn‚Äôt be taxed. But I assumed those gifts would have to come out of the estate itself. There would still be tax to pay if I was the one giving to charity.

The solicitor confirmed my suspicions but did offer another solution. He said that we could rewrite my gran‚Äôs will as long as it was within 2 years of her death. This way, we could change her wishes to leave some money to charity. He was dubious that it would be worth the savings in inheritance tax. Depending on the size of the gift, it might involve selling stocks and shares that would be better off holding. I told him that I intended to leave my entire share to charity after giving what my parents needed to buy a house. He was pretty taken aback. I realised then that it wasn‚Äôt a very standard request.

I began researching charities. And as I did so, I started to become more confident in the choice I was making. I realised that this amount of money could really make a difference to a lot of people. Well, I did know that before but only intellectually. I was so swept up by the guilt and shame that I didn‚Äôt give myself much space to feel anything positive about this inheritance. I told myself I had no right to feel good about giving to charity when I wasn‚Äôt really the one giving that money. And yet, as I thought about the possibilities of what that money could do, I couldn‚Äôt help but start to feel hopeful.

The first charity I chose was GiveDirectly. It‚Äôs one that I have followed for a while and have included in my own will. Their mission is simple, to give cash to people living in poverty. When I first heard about them, their mission really resonated with me. A lot of people just need money, they don‚Äôt need to be patronised by others deciding how that money should be spent. GiveDirectly is also recommended by groups like GiveWell that compare the effectiveness of different charities. I was also happy to see that they have two response programs for those economically affected by COVID-19, one in Africa and another in the US.

For my two other chosen charities, I decided to look closer to home. One was The Trussell Trust. They are a charity that supports a network of food banks up and down the country. I chose them because, sadly, the need for food banks is only rising.

Another pressing cause I wanted to support was trans folks. The UK is known globally as a hotbed for anti-trans sentiment. A few months ago the High Court made a ruling that effectively denied under-16s life-saving treatment for their crippling gender dysphoria. I say ‚Äúlife-saving‚Äù because nearly half (48%) of trans people in Britain have attempted suicide and puberty blockers have been shown to lower the risk of suicide. So that‚Äôs why I chose the charity Mermaids. They support transgender, nonbinary and gender-diverse kids by providing a secure online community, helpline service, local groups as well as a bunch of other services. They also work in the wider area of advocacy and activism, educating society on gender identity and trans issues.

So, where does everything stand now? A deed of variation is currently being processed to rewrite my gran‚Äôs will. Instead of the estate being split by thirds, a sum of money and an entire investment account is being allocated my dad. The rest (about ¬£110,000 - ¬£115,000) is being shared between GiveDirectly (50%), The Trussell Trust (25%) and Mermaids (25%). This means that my dad is getting about ¬£100k more than was originally planned. Therefore, my parents have agreed that any money they don‚Äôt need for the house will go to those three charities. Of course, this is an agreement based on trust, it‚Äôs not legally binding.

As for me, I‚Äôm looking forward to when everything is finalised and the money starts being distributed. I used to feel dread towards that date. I have also let go of most of my guilt and instead am immensely grateful for the gift my gran gave. Not only is it going to help a lot of people, but the inheritance has forced me to think deeply about what I value and who I am.

There are some interesting parallels to draw with my gran‚Äôs own story. She inherited the vast majority of her wealth from a family friend when she was still a young woman. It feels kind of poetic that the money she inherited and stored away in assets is finally going to be released into the world and do good.

Looking back over this journey, I don‚Äôt think I took the healthiest approach to inheriting all this money. I probably should have confronted it earlier, spoke to people about it, maybe even sought a therapist. But despite that, I am happy with the end result and I know the guilt helped push me towards that. A big learning for me is that I should embrace the guilt more, listen to what it has to say and let it pull me where I need to go.

As a final note, I want to highlight that this is my own story and I am in a uniquely privileged position to be able to give all my inheritance away. If my circumstances were different, if I had dependents, struggled to make ends meet or had aspirations for myself that I couldn‚Äôt afford, I might have chosen differently. The relationship you have with the person who has died also has a huge impact on how you feel about the money. If my gran had worked her entire life to give me this money and had specific wishes for how I should use it, I might have gone along with that.

item.title: I read my first book in Japanese üéâ
item.description: My 2020 goal was to read Harry Potter and the Philosopher‚Äôs Stone (or „Éè„É™„Éº„Éª„Éù„ÉÉ„Çø„Éº„Å®Ë≥¢ËÄÖ„ÅÆÁü≥) by the end of the year. Two weeks ago, I finished it!
item.content:encoded:
Last year, I embarked on a journey to learn Japanese. I set myself an objective to read Harry Potter and the Philosopher‚Äôs Stone (or „Éè„É™ „Éº„Éª„Éù„ÉÉ„Çø„Éº„Å®Ë≥¢ËÄÖ„ÅÆÁü≥) by the end of 2020. Two weeks ago, I accomplished this goal. In this post, I describe my journey so far, approach to reading, and will present some fun stats and graphs I recorded along the way.

Back in April, I suddenly found myself with a lot more time on my hands. The UK was under strict lockdown. Not having to commute to work, socialise, or even go outside at all, meant I gained several hours a day. At first, I spent all that extra time playing Animal Crossing (200 hours within the first month of its release). On my third attempt to landscape my Animal Crossing island, I stopped. I was wasting an opportunity. If there was any time to reignite my interest in learning Japanese, this was it.

My previous attempts to study the language were largely unsuccessful. I dabbled a bit with language learning apps and lost interest quite quickly. Even though I am fortunate enough to understand a fair amount of Japanese already (thanks, mum), I just didn‚Äôt have much experience or confidence in being able to acquire a new language. My time learning French and German at school taught me that I could rote-learn vocabulary lists, memorise a script by heart and get decent exam results. But I didn‚Äôt retain any of that information a month later let alone years after I left school. The lesson I took away from it all was that I just wasn‚Äôt suited to languages. Plus, I didn‚Äôt find it very interesting either.

Nevertheless, I was committed to give learning Japanese a proper go. It felt like I would be foresaking my heritage if I didn‚Äôt.

So, my self-directed language learning journey began with learning how to learn. I quickly realised, though it should have been obvious before, that picking up a second language isn‚Äôt anything special. Most sources say that over half of the world‚Äôs population is multilingual. Clearly, I didn‚Äôt need to be gifted or attuned to languages. I just needed time, dedication, and effective learning methods.

I also discovered that it isn‚Äôt generally recommended to learn a language in the way I was taught at school. Rote-learning vocabulary lists and studying textbooks only get you so far. At some point you need to confront what you‚Äôve learned in the real world. This can transform the vague, tenuous connections you have between foreign sounds and meaning in your native language into something concrete and meaningful in its own right. It‚Äôs that extra step between knowing that the bunch of lines Èùí can mean ‚Äúgreen‚Äù or ‚Äúblue‚Äù and having the correct colour wash over you, without thought, when seeing that character in context. For that, you need to immerse yourself in the language and be exposed to the vast variety of ways each kanji, word, grammar point, etc. can be used.

This approach to language learning seemed very appealing. If I could pick up Japanese just by reading stuff in Japanese and listening to stuff in Japanese, that sounds like I could actually enjoy myself.

At the start of April, I set my focus on improving my reading ability. Doing so would unlock a whole world of material to immerse myself in. But I was starting from pretty much square one. Japanese has three writing systems - hiragana, katakana and kanji. The first two I knew well enough at the time, there are only 46 characters in each. Kanji, on the other hand, is a whole other beast and has thousands of characters with multiple ways to read and understand each of them. I was familiar with about 20 kanji at the time. The average Japanese adult can read over 3000.

So, knowing that I wanted to get better at reading, I just needed a direction to work towards. This goal of reading Harry Potter became my lighthouse and gave purpose to all the other studies I was undertaking.

Of course, I didn‚Äôt just spend the past 8 months slowly working through the book. Before I could even get started on the first page, I spent half a year buried in textbooks, reading short form text such as NHK Easy News articles, and reviewing kanji and vocab using spaced repetition techiques. In future, I might write another post going over the resources and methods I used in more detail. But for now, I‚Äôll focus on how I tackled reading my first book in Japanese. üìñ

Why Harry Potter?

Learning a new language unlocks a whole new world of rich content to explore. It‚Äôs the reason a lot of people study a new language in the first place. So, you might be wondering why I chose a book that‚Äôs originally written in English. A story I‚Äôm already very familiar with and wouldn‚Äôt be getting much out of by reading it again in its impure, translated form.

Discovering a new narrative wasn‚Äôt the reason I chose Harry Potter. I simply wanted to get better at Japanese. And it‚Äôs much easier to get started with something that you are already familiar with.

For starters, you have a lot of context to full back on.
